concepts.content: A relation between variables x and y is any set of points in the (x, y) plane. We say that the points connect the two variables.
A relation is often expressed in the form of an equation connecting the variables x and y.
y = x + 3 and x = y^2 are the equations of two relations. Each equation generates a set of ordered pairs, which we can graph.

Not all relations can be defined by an equation. Examples: (1) The set of all points in the first quadrant is the relation x > 0, y > 0. (2) A finite set of 13 points form a relation that can be described as a finite set of points, but not by an equation.
A function is a relation in which no two different ordered pairs have the same x-coordinate or first component.
Suppose a relation is given as an equation. If the substitution of any value for x results in at most one value of y, then the relation is a function.
y = 3x - 1 is a function, since for any value of x there is only one corresponding value of y.
x = y^2 is not a function, since if x = 4 then y = +/-2.

sections.title: Geometric Test or Vertical Line Test for Functions

concepts.content: Suppose we draw all possible vertical lines on the graph of a relation. If each line cuts the graph at most once, then the relation is a function. If at least one line cuts the graph more than once, then the relation is not a function.
If a graph contains a small open circle, this point is not included.
If a graph contains a small filled-in circle, this point is included.
If a graph contains an arrowhead at an end, then the graph continues indefinitely in that general direction, or the shape may repeat as it has done previously.
Function machines are sometimes used to illustrate how functions behave. If we use f to represent a particular function, we can write 'f is the function that will convert x into 2x + 3'.
The function can be written as: f : x |-> 2x + 3, where function f such that x is converted into 2x + 3.
Two other equivalent forms we use are f(x) = 2x + 3 and y = 2x + 3.
f(x) is the value of y for a given value of x, so y = f(x). f(x) is read as 'f of x'.
y = f(x) is sometimes called the function value or image of x.
The domain of a relation is the set of values which the variable on the horizontal axis can take. This variable is usually x.
The range of a relation is the set of values which the variable on the vertical axis can take. This variable is usually y.
The domain and range of a relation can be described using set notation, interval notation, or a number line graph.
{x | x >= 3} means x >= 3, the set of all x such that x is greater than or equal to 3.
{x | x < 2} means x < 2, the set of all x such that x is less than 2.
{x | -2 < x <= 1} means -2 < x <= 1, the set of all x such that x is between -2 and 1, including 1.
{x | x <= 0 or x > 4} means x <= 0 or x > 4, the set of all x such that x is less than or equal to 0, or greater than 4.
To fully describe a function, we need both a rule and a domain.
If a domain is not specified, we use the natural domain, which is the largest part of R (real numbers) for which f(x) is defined.
Natural domains: x^2 has domain x in R; sqrt(x) has domain x >= 0; 1/x has domain x != 0; 1/sqrt(x) has domain x > 0.
Given f : x |-> f(x) and g : x |-> g(x), the composite function of f and g will convert x into f(g(x)).
f o g is used to represent the composite function of f and g. It means 'f following g'.
(f o g)(x) = f(g(x)) or f o g : x |-> f(g(x))
Consider f : x |-> x^4 and g : x |-> 2x + 3. f o g means that g converts x to 2x + 3 and then f converts (2x + 3) to (2x + 3)^4.

worked_examples.title: Example 1
worked_examples.problem: Which of the following relations are functions?

content.graph_description: Curved line passing vertical line test
content.answer: a function - every vertical line we could draw cuts the graph only once.

content.graph_description: Wavy curve passing vertical line test
content.answer: a function - every vertical line cuts the graph only once.

content.graph_description: Sideways curve failing vertical line test
content.answer: not a function - at least one vertical line cuts the graph more than once.

worked_examples.title: Example 2
worked_examples.problem: Which of these relations are functions?

content.solution: Every vertical line we could draw cuts the graph only once.
This vertical line cuts the graph twice.
content.answer: The relation is not a function.

worked_examples.title: Example 2 (Function Notation)
worked_examples.problem: If f : x |-> 2x^2 - 3x, find the value of: a) f(5)  b) f(-4)

worked_examples.title: Example 3
worked_examples.problem: If f(x) = 5 - x - x^2, find in simplest form: a) f(-x)  b) f(x+2)  c) f(x-1) - 5

worked_examples.title: Example 4
worked_examples.problem: For each of the following graphs, state the domain and range.

solution.graph_description: Curve with endpoint at (8, -2) and passing through (4, 3)

worked_examples.title: Example 5 (Domain and Range)
worked_examples.problem: State the domain and range of each of the following functions: a) f(x) = sqrt(x-5)  b) f(x) = 1/(x-5)  c) f(x) = 1/sqrt(x-5)

solution.analysis: sqrt(x-5) is defined when x - 5 >= 0, so x >= 5. A square root cannot be negative.
1/(x-5) is defined when x - 5 != 0, so x != 5. No matter how large or small x is, y = f(x) is never zero.
1/sqrt(x-5) is defined when x - 5 > 0, so x > 5. y = f(x) is always positive and never zero.

worked_examples.title: Example 5 (Find Domain)
worked_examples.problem: Find the domain of: a) f(x) = 2/sqrt(x+3)  b) f(x) = sqrt(x) + sqrt(5-x)

solution.analysis: f(x) = 2/sqrt(x+3) is defined when x + 3 > 0, so x > -3
f(x) = sqrt(x) + sqrt(5-x) is defined when x >= 0 and 5 - x >= 0, so x >= 0 and x <= 5

problems.question: The managers of a new amusement park are discussing the schedule of ticket prices. Maurice suggests the table alongside. Explain why this relation between age and cost is not a function, and discuss the problems that this will cause.
The graph alongside shows the curves y = x^2 and y^2 = x.

parts.text: Discuss the similarities and differences between the curves, including whether each curve is a function. You may also consider what transformation(s) map one curve onto the other.
Using y^2 = x, we can write y = +/-sqrt(x). i) What part of the graph of y^2 = x corresponds to y = sqrt(x)? ii) Is y = sqrt(x) a function? Explain your answer.
